discussion.content: Firmware upgrade seems to be common for a lot of answers.

comments.content: yeah, you're right

discussion.content: Speaks of vulnerabilities so the answer is patches and upgrades

The question should really say a "known vulnerability" or reference a zero-day attack in one way or another. Almost every single system in existence has a vulnerability and every single attack utilizes some sort of vulnerability in one way or another. I see what they are going for, and I agree that it is the correct answer, but these questions, like most CompTIA questions are terribly written.

choices.D: Review and modify the firewall rules.
choices.A: Verify the default passwords have been changed.

questions.question_text: A vulnerability that would allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to originate a DoS attack was found in a DHCP client implementation of a switch. Which of the following would BEST resolve the issue?

Log files show the admin user has logged into a public-facing device on several occasions in the evening. None of the technicians admit to doing any after-hours work, and the password has been changed several times but failed to prevent the logins. Which of the following should be the NEXT step to attempt to harden the device?

discussion.content: Resetting the two factor token will back to default, so not a good choice. The best option is to upgrade the firmware

"public facing device", so one would think it would be accessible over the internet. Yet disabling unused ports is the answer? 
some of these questions are so confusing
keyword here is "harden the device" falls under firmware upgrade / patch update.
I think B might be the answer here. Because the hacker may have the 2FA device, which is how they keep getting in despite the password changes.
Iâ€™m unsure as to what is the correct answer.
So the answer is assuming none of the admins log in to the device so is suggesting disable the ports used to login?

comments.content: I would agree with you except that every time I try to look up "two-factor token" the explanation evolves into "2FA" - two factor authentication. I believe that's as simple as user name and password. The question seems to imply that the user name on the admin account is "admin", that's why they have to ask each technician and rely on the truthfulness of their answer. Rather than "reset" the two-factor "token" they should redesign their login to have each technician have their own, individual login which should enable tracking through the logs... or is that not possible?

discussion.content: If your own technicians need to get access to this device, then disabling ports doesn't seem to be the best choice... if there was some indication of a "vulnerability", then I'd say D:upgrade firmware, but no mention of that... the Q also says the password has been changed several times already, which seems to TRY to eliminate B, however the Q doesn't mention using 2-factor authentication, just a password. However, I think B is the only logical answer as the Q is written. Keep in mind, exam dumps are mostly created by test takers' "memory". So the questions are most likely not exact, nor are the answers always correct. Use them for what they are, do not memorize answers, verify and research what you don't know and you'll do great on the exam!
why disable unused port? Which port? some 2FA can lock who is the admin user

choices.D: Create two SSIDs, one to support CCMP-AES encryption and one with TKIP-RC4 encryption.
choices.A: Configure the APs to use LEAP authentication to support WPA rather than WPA2 for full compatibility.
choices.C: Connect the legacy devices with a PSK while the modern devices should use the more secure EAP.
choices.B: Connect modern devices under the 5GHz band while dedicating the 2.4GHz band to legacy devices.

discussion.content: B. Configure modern devices under the 5GHz band while dedicating the 2.4GHz band to legacy devices. is the right answer with no issue

comments.content: 2.4 GHz is not working on 802.11a wifi set up, it works with 5GHz wifi.
You are right : KEY WORDs MOST SECURE

802.11a works only with 5Ghz, so B is wrong.
A is wrong because using WPA for full compatibility is not the "MOST" secure method
D Could be right but in that way the devices would't go thorough the process of 802.1X authorization, but would just work in a "Persona - pre shared key" mode.
That leaves only C: connect old devices in "Personal PSK" mode and get modern devices authenticate using EAP (802.1X) and encrypted with AES.

discussion.content:
"the MOST secure method of connecting all devices <while avoiding a performance impact to modern wireless devices>"
if any of the old legacy POS devices is connected to WAP, the throughput will be stuck at 802.11a (54Mbps) so it does have impact if you don't separate modern devices from legacy devices.

So, it is necessary to build two APs with two different SSIDs(one for 11ac(CCMP-AES) the other for 11a with TKIP-RC4) to accommodate them all.
for this reason i will choose D.

comments.content: Yes you can. But it's not happen to be the MOST secure. TKIP-RC4 is a weak encryption method.

questions.question_text: A network technician has deployed a new 802.11ac network and discovers some of the legacy POS equipment only supports WPA and 802.11a. Which of the following is the MOST secure method of connecting all devices while avoiding a performance impact to modern wireless devices?
Which of the following BEST describes the characteristics of a differential backup solution?

discussion.content:
I believe the correct answer should be D
https://www.computerweekly.com/news/1347703/Incremental-vs-differential-backup-A-comparison

The answer is D for sure. None of the three backup types taught use the date to decide what to backup, so A and C are out. B backs up all files - that's a full. The last option remaining is D. The official CompTIA Network + student guide says: 
Differential All data modified since the last full backup.
backup/restore time: Moderate/moderate (no more than two sets)
attribute: Not Cleared

Selected Answer: D
The answer is D.
if you don't choose D you're gay

comments.content: I think you just like the D. :)

discussion.content: Yeah I think its D as well
A would be correct if differential backup is done everyday. I think for D to be correct, after backup the archive bit should be cleared, otherwise the files would be constantly backup up

comments.content:
D states it does not clear the achieve bi
 D seems to be logical answer.
what you're saying is an incremental backup. differential backup is the one that is performed since the last full backup, hence we are not clearing the archive bit

choices.A: Backs up files with the creation or modified date as the current date.
choices.C: Backs up files with a date earlier than today's date with a clear archive bit.
choices.D: Backs up files with the archive bit set but does not clear the bit.
choices.B: Backs up all files and sets the archive bit.

discussion.content:
I though the answer was D, but i went and tested the answer in a lab enviroment, and yes it's A.
Remember that LAN traffic uses MAC addresses, so as long as both the router and the PC are in the same network, they will both communicate. This scenario represents a problem in which TCP/IP configuration is done manually in which errors like configuring the default gateway as 192.168.0.11 instead of 192.168.0.1 can happen. If you ping the Router from the PC, you will get connectivity, but when the PC wants to communicate outside the LAN, there will be no communication because of the wrong default gateway. This is a tricky one

comments.content: if the default gateway is already wrong like 192.168.0.11 instead of 192.168.0.1, then how possibly can a PC ping to the Router?

Because the default gateway doesn't have to be the router's IP. PCs have routing tables and they get that from ARP. Your ARP cache can have your router's actual IP address and that's what they use to communicate.

Which lab environment? Please provide link lol
This sounds like something I could use

discussion.content: If the technician can ping the workstation from the accounting department's router (and there is no mention of the staff person having difficulties connecting to accounting resources), we can assume the workstation is in the correct VLAN. The only other answer that makes sense is an incorrect default gateway - likely due to manual misconfiguration (they make no mention of using DHCP, so manual entry errors should be considered). A makes sense - it's just a poorly worded question to make you think it through.
I got to admit, no regular user would use a command prompt to test why the internet isn't working, the user tried to access the internet, and because of wrong Default Gateway, they couldn't
The fact that he can ping from the accounting department eliminates improper VLAN . So it is A
Option D is the right answer

comments.content: in a real life situation the gateway would not be messed, if the gateway one is messed up for one router that causes other devices to mess up and for then; the company/place/etc loses money.
How so? Adds an additional layer of confusion to the discussion above.

discussion.content: When a host needs to send a message to another host located on the same network, it can forward the message directly. However, when a host needs to send a message to a remote network, it must use the router, also known as the default gateway. This is because the data link frame address of the remote destination host cannot be used directly. Instead, the IP packet has to be sent to the router (default gateway) and the router will forward the packet toward its destination. Therefore, if the default gateway is incorrectly configured, the host can communicate with other hosts on the same network, but not with hosts on remote networks.

I'm so confused, can someone please explain this to me? :)

You're assuming that the default gateway is given within a DHCP lease scope and not manually configured. If it is the wrong VLAN then it is likely that the subnet mask, default gateway, and everything else is gonna be misconfigured.
It would depend on if everyone has a static IP address or if they're using DHCP.

you don't assign VLANs to a workstation, you assign them to a Port. if they swapped out their workstation with a new one, they would probably be in the same port. 

what kills me about so many comptia questions is they make you assume that manually configured IP address are in use everywhere, which is the LAST thing any reputable tech/network would be doing.

questions.question_text: A network technician receives a call from a user in the accounting department stating that Internet connectivity has been lost after receiving a new workstation. No other users in accounting are reporting similar issues. The network technician is able to ping the machine from the accounting department's router, but is not able to ping the machine from the IT network. Which of the following is MOST likely the cause?
